awd_titl_txt: Outsourcing Attention Management to Human and Artificial Agents in Organizations
awd_abstract_narration:
As the capabilities of artificial intelligence advance, organizations are faced with new opportunities to outsource tasks and decisions about their practices to machines. The introduction of artificially intelligent (AI) assistants to workplaces and their effect on organizational performance has garnered both excitement and concern. While some executives praise AI and laud its value as a solution for organizational problems, other workers fear that artificial intelligence will threaten and displace their work. This study avoids such generalizations by focusing on how the use of artificially intelligent agents in scheduling shapes how managers direct their attention, which in turn shapes organizational performance and the economy at large. Understanding these processes is important because of the broad consequences that entrusting attention management to AI will have, from influencing innovation to enabling or inhibiting organizational learning by affecting the knowledge to which organizations have access. The findings of the study will shape our understanding of what work technology is equipped to do, how organizational members should be trained to work with AI, and how to mitigate unintended consequences of using AI to guide our decision making.

This project investigates how decisions about time and attention are outsourced to both AI and human agents and utilizes ethnographic methods to gather rich interview and observational data from several field sites. In doing so, the study contributes to intellectual conversations in three main areas. First, the findings of this study will help revise existing theoretical work using an attention-based view of the firm to show how other people shape leaders' attention. Second, the findings will develop new theory about the relationship between time and attention. Though existing empirical evidence suggests that decisions about time affect attention allocation, the proposed comparative study will provide greater understanding of the mechanisms through which decisions about time come to bear on attention. Third, the study contributes to the larger area of artificial intelligence and the changing nature of work and organizing. Its findings will illuminate the choices that developers make in designing artificially intelligent technologies and identify the attributes of these tools that organizations should consider when deciding to implement them into their work.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
In today’s fast-paced work environments, senior leaders often face an overwhelming number of demands on their time and attention. To help manage these challenges, organizations increasingly rely on assistants—whether human or artificial—to handle scheduling and prioritize tasks. This project explored the growing role of artificial intelligence (AI) assistants alongside traditional executive and virtual assistants in managing the time and attention of organizational leaders. The research examined how these different types of assistants shape leaders’ focus, decision-making, and overall organizational performance.

 

Intellectual Merit

 

This study extended our understanding of the role assistants play in shaping attention management in organizations, which is critical to strategic decision-making, innovation, and adaptability. Key findings include:

• Assistant Comparisons: AI assistants, executive assistants, and virtual assistants each bring unique strengths and challenges. AI assistants excel at efficiency and scalability, executive assistants provide personalized and context-rich support, and virtual assistants offer flexibility and insights drawn from working across multiple industries.

• Attention Shaping: Decisions made by assistants about scheduling not only manage time but also direct leaders’ attention toward specific people, opportunities, and tasks. These decisions influence strategic priorities, collaboration, and the ability to respond to emerging challenges.

• Theoretical Advancements: The study expanded the attention-based view of the firm by showing how outsourced attention management reshapes leadership focus and organizational adaptation. It also offered new insights into the relationship between time and attention in organizational settings.

 

Broader Impacts

 

The findings have practical implications for organizations and contributed to educational initiatives:

• Organizational Practices: This research helps organizations understand how to effectively implement AI tools and manage human-AI collaboration. By highlighting best practices for assistant use, the study provides actionable insights for leaders seeking to balance efficiency with strategic focus.

• Education and Training: The project informed the development of new courses, including Technology and Attention in Organizations, which prepares students to navigate the intersection of technology and organizational practices. Workshops for academics and practitioners shared findings and fostered dialogue about the future of AI in the workplace.

• Diversity and Inclusion: The project engaged students from underrepresented groups, providing training and mentorship in cutting-edge research methods. This effort promotes equity and inclusion in technology-related fields.

 

Project Outcomes

 

Over the course of the award, the project accomplished the following:

1. Conducted 180 interviews and 1,200 hours of ethnographic observations across three organizational contexts to compare AI, executive, and virtual assistants.

2. Partnered with leading organizations to collect and analyze data, offering a detailed picture of how assistants operate in practice.

3. Developed theoretical models explaining how outsourced attention management affects organizational outcomes, including innovation, strategy implementation, and performance.

4. Created and updated courses to educate future leaders and researchers about the role of AI and attention management in organizations.

5. Hosted workshops to disseminate findings to academic and practitioner audiences, encouraging the adoption of best practices.

 

In summary, this project provided a comprehensive analysis of how human and AI assistants influence time and attention management in organizations. By bridging theory and practice, the research not only advanced academic understanding but also delivered practical guidance for organizations navigating the complexities of digital transformation. These contributions will continue to shape how leaders and organizations manage attention in an increasingly technology-driven world.
